Introduction

X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the absence of mature B cells.  Patients with XLA present with recurrent infections as transplacental immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies wane after age 6 months.

Pathogenesis



B cell maturation begins in the bone marrow, where hematopoietic stem cells differentiate into immature B cells (

figure 1
).  Immature B cells then migrate to secondary lymphoid tissues (eg, spleen, lymph nodes), where they complete maturation.  Mature B cells aggregate in the cortex of lymph nodes to form lymphoid follicles (
figure 2
).  Upon antigenic stimulation, mature B cells migrate to secondary follicles, where they proliferate and differentiate into immunoglobulin-producing plasma cells in the germinal center.



XLA is caused by a genetic mutation in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene on the X chromosome.  BTK is expressed in CD19+ cells and is involved in B cell maturation, as it is a protein that transduces signals from the preâ€“B-cell receptor.  Without BTK-mediated signal transduction, B cell maturation is arrested at the preâ€“B-cell stage, limiting clonal expansion and differentiation.  As a result, a profound reduction or absence of mature B cells occurs, resulting in an absence of lymphoid follicles, germinal centers, and plasma cells.  Therefore, patients with XLA have a reduction in all major immunoglobulin classes (eg, IgG, IgA, IgM) and are unable to mount an effective humoral immune response, increasing susceptibility to infection.

Clinical presentation



XLA typically presents with recurrent infections in late infancy (age >6 months) as transplacental IgG wanes.  Infections are typically bacterial but certain viral, fungal, and parasitic infections are also characteristic of XLA.  Sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections are most common due in part to low secretory IgA.  Patients are particularly susceptible to infection with pathogens that require antibody opsonization for phagocytosis, including:



  • Encapsulated bacteria (eg, Haemophilus influenzae type B, Streptococcus pneumoniae) (
    figure 3
    ):  Patients cannot mount an effective humoral response to routine childhood vaccinations and may present with vaccine-preventable disease, regardless of vaccination status.
  • Enterovirus:  is a common cause of self-limited illness (eg, herpangina; hand, foot, and mouth disease) in immunocompetent children.  Without neutralizing antibodies, patients are at risk for chronic infection with life-threatening complications (eg, meningoencephalitis).
  • Giardia lamblia:  Patients are at risk for chronic infection with diarrhea and nutrient loss, which can delay growth and development over time.


Physical examination often shows small or absent lymphoid tissue (eg, tonsils, adenoids).

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected XLA (eg, older infant male with a history of recurrent infections and absent lymphoid tissue), initial laboratory evaluation includes:



  • Complete blood count (CBC) can be misleadingly normal because B cells comprise only about 25% of total lymphocytes or show decreased absolute lymphocyte count.  Otherwise, CBC is normal.
  • Flow cytometry shows reduced or absent CD19+ B cells with normal CD3+ T cell concentrations.
  • Quantitative immunoglobulin levels show reduced or absent levels of all immunoglobulin isotypes (eg, IgG, IgA, IgM, IgE, IgD).
  • Serology shows reduced or absent antibody response to routine childhood vaccinations.


Genetic testing can identify the underlying mutation in the BTK gene, confirming the diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for XLA includes:



  • Common variable immunodeficiency:  presents with recurrent infections due to low IgG, IgM, and IgA in adolescent males and females.  Although the differentiation of activated B cells into plasma cells is impaired, CD19+ B cell count is normal.
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID):  presents with severe and recurrent bacterial, viral, fungal, or opportunistic infections due to combined cellular and humoral immunodeficiency in late infancy.  In contrast to XLA, B cell and T cell counts are reduced or absent.  SCID is most commonly X-linked.
  • CD40 ligand deficiency (X-linked hyper-IgM syndrome):  presents with recurrent sinopulmonary infections due to low IgG in male infants.  IgM is elevated due to defective class-switch recombination.
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome:  is an X-linked disorder characterized by immunodeficiency, microthrombocytopenia, and eczema.  B cell and T cell counts are classically low but can be normal in infancy.  Quantitative immunoglobulin analysis shows low-to-normal IgG and IgM with elevated IgA and IgE.
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy:  is characterized by low IgG, variable IgM, and normal IgA levels; B cell count is normal.  Patients develop mild, recurrent sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections.  Immunoglobulin levels generally normalize by age 9-15 months.

Management



No cure exists for XLA, but effective management can prevent serious infections and improve quality of life.  Management involves infection prevention and immunoglobulin replacement therapy.



  • Infection prevention

    • Antimicrobial prophylaxis:  may be indicated for patients with recurrent infections despite adequate immunoglobulin replacement therapy.
    • Killed vaccines:  Although patients cannot mount an effective antibody response, killed vaccines may be considered for possible T cellâ€“mediated immune response that would offer additional immunity beyond that of immunoglobulin replacement therapy.  In contrast, live vaccines (eg, MMR, rotavirus) are not recommended due to the risk of severe vaccine-associated infections.
    • Aggressive treatment of infections:  includes initial use of broad-spectrum antimicrobials at the earliest sign of infection.
  • Immunoglobulin replacement therapy (eg, intravenous immunoglobulin [IVIG]):  consists of pooled immunoglobulins from thousands of donors, providing passive immunity against common pathogens.  However, IVIG offers minimal protection from uncommon pathogens, leaving patients susceptible.  In addition, IVIG does not replace the immediate increase in antibody production upon exposure to a known pathogen in immunocompetent patients.


Genetic counseling may be beneficial for families with a history of XLA.

Prognosis



With prompt diagnosis and appropriate management, patients with XLA can lead relatively normal lives, although they remain at increased susceptibility to infections.  Regular IVIG transfusions improve long-term outcomes; however, patients are at risk for pulmonary (due to chronic lung infections) and neurologic (due to chronic enteroviral infection) complications.  Although the exact association remains uncertain, patients appear to be at increased risk for malignancy, autoimmune conditions, sensorineural hearing loss, and eczema.

Summary



X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia is a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the absence of mature B cells (
